title: Government of New Mexico
text:
The government of <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a> is the governmental structure of the state of <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a> as established by the <a href="Constitution%20of%20New%20Mexico">Constitution of New Mexico</a>. The executive is composed of the <a href="Governor%20of%20New%20Mexico">governor</a>, several other statewide elected officials and the governor's cabinet. The <a href="New%20Mexico%20Legislature">New Mexico Legislature</a> consists of the <a href="New%20Mexico%20House%20of%20Representatives">House of Representatives</a> and <a href="New%20Mexico%20Senate">Senate</a>. The judiciary is composed of the <a href="New%20Mexico%20Supreme%20Court">New Mexico Supreme Court</a> and lower courts. There is also local government, consisting of county administrations, city governments, and special districts.

Legislature.
The <a href="New%20Mexico%20Legislature">New Mexico Legislature</a> is a bicameral body made up of the 70-member <a href="New%20Mexico%20House%20of%20Representatives">New Mexico House of Representatives</a> and the 42-member <a href="New%20Mexico%20Senate">New Mexico Senate</a>. The New Mexico Constitution limits the regular session to sixty calendar days, and every other year it is thirty days. The <a href="Lieutenant%20Governor%20of%20New%20Mexico">lieutenant governor</a> presides over the Senate, while the speaker of the House is elected from that body in a closed door majority member caucus. Both have wide latitude in choosing committee membership in their respective houses and have a large impact on lawmaking in the state.
Judiciary.
The <a href="New%20Mexico%20Supreme%20Court">New Mexico Supreme Court</a> is the <a href="supreme%20court">highest court</a>. It is primarily an appellate court, only having original jurisdiction in a limited number of actions; <a href="criminal%20law">criminal</a> cases in which the <a href="Capital%20punishment%20in%20the%20United%20States">death penalty</a> or <a href="life%20imprisonment">life imprisonment</a> is sought, appeals from the <a href="New%20Mexico%20Public%20Regulation%20Commission">New Mexico Public Regulation Commission</a>, and cases involving the <a href="writ">writ</a> of <a href="habeas%20corpus">habeas corpus</a> are reviewed directly by the Supreme Court. The court's five justices are chosen by statewide election, or appointed by the governor if to fill a seat that has become vacant mid-term.
The <a href="New%20Mexico%20Court%20of%20Appeals">New Mexico Court of Appeals</a> is the intermediate-level <a href="appellate%20court">appellate court</a>. The court has general <a href="appellate%20jurisdiction">appellate jurisdiction</a> over the district courts and certain state agencies. Ten judges preside, sitting in panels of three.
The <a href="New%20Mexico%20district%20courts">New Mexico district courts</a> are courts of general jurisdiction. They hear cases involving: tort, contract, real property rights, estate; exclusive domestic relations, mental health, appeals for administrative agencies and lower courts, miscellaneous civil jurisdiction; misdemeanor; exclusive criminal appeals jurisdiction; and exclusive juvenile jurisdiction. There are thirteen judicial districts.
The <a href="New%20Mexico%20magistrate%20courts">New Mexico magistrate courts</a> are courts of limited jurisdiction. They hear cases involving: tort, contract, landlord/tenant rights ($0–10,000); felony preliminary hearings; and misdemeanor, DWI/DUI and other traffic violations. There are fifty-four magistrate courts.
The <a href="New%20Mexico%20probate%20courts">New Mexico probate courts</a> are courts of limited jurisdiction and do not hold jury trials. There is one for each of New Mexico's thirty-three counties.
The <a href="New%20Mexico%20municipal%20courts">New Mexico municipal courts</a> are courts of limited jurisdiction and do not hold jury trials. They hear cases involving: petty misdemeanors, DWI/DUI, traffic violations and other municipal ordinance violations.
The <a href="Bernalillo%20County%20Metropolitan%20Court">Bernalillo County Metropolitan Court</a> is a court of limited jurisdiction of <a href="Bernalillo%20County%2C%20New%20Mexico">Bernalillo County</a>. It hears cases involving: tort, contract, landlord and tenant rights ($0–10,000); felony first appearances; misdemeanor, DWI/DUI, domestic violence, and other traffic violations.
Local government.
Local government in New Mexico consists of <a href="List%20of%20counties%20in%20New%20Mexico">counties</a> and <a href="List%20of%20settlements%20in%20New%20Mexico">municipalities</a>. There are thirty-three counties, of which <a href="Bernalillo%20County%2C%20New%20Mexico">Bernalillo County</a>, containing the state's largest city <a href="Albuquerque%2C%20New%20Mexico">Albuquerque</a>, is the most populous. Counties are usually governed by an elected five-member county commission, sheriff, assessor, clerk and treasurer. A municipality may call itself a <a href="village">village</a>, <a href="town">town</a>, or <a href="city">city</a>, and there is no distinction in law and no correlation to any particular form (Mayor-Council, Commission-Manager, etc.). Municipal elections are non-partisan. In addition, limited local authority can be vested in special districts and landowners' associations.
